utterances: He was very close to and inevitably going to recuse himself for a variety of reasons.
We also were aware of facts that I can't discuss in an open setting that would make his continued engagement in a Russia-related investigation problematic.
So there'd been back-and-forth about whether Jeff Sessions was going to testify publicly or privately.
It will be public today.
But that's quite an insinuation James Comey is making.
Is Jeff Sessions in danger of losing his job?
Well, they have floated rumors to that effect from the White House.
But like all the rumors that come out of the White House, they're hard to know which are real, which are a spur-of-the-moment fake news from the White House.
I don't know whether it is or not.
He's been very close.
He's acted almost like the president's personal attorney instead of acting like the attorney for all of the country.
I think right now the president wants people who will not delve into his involvement with Russia.
Just briefly, it seems you've mentioned several times that you have felt confused or out of the loop or unclear on what is true and not true coming out of the White House.
Is that hard to navigate as a lawmaker?
It is very difficult, and that's why I think Mr. Sessions has to come in under oath.
He'll go before the intelligence committee.
Eventually, has to come before the judiciary committee...
Yeah.
...And testify under oath.
And answer questions.
Senator Pat Leahy of Vermont, thanks so much for your time.
Take care.
Here in Los Angeles, controversy over a police standoff that left a 19-month-old girl and her father dead.
Susie Pena and her father, 34-year-old Jose Raul Pena, were killed by SWAT officers on Sunday after a fierce gunfight.
Officers say Pena was using his daughter as a human shield as he shot at them.
At a press conference yesterday, the toddler's mother, Lorena Lopez, offered an impassioned defense.
(Through Translator) He was the best father I've ever known.
He had a great love for his daughter.
He stayed with here while I was at work.
He was a good man.
He would read to her.
The Los Angeles Police Department has seen more than its share of controversy in recent years, and once again officers are defending themselves against accusations of excessive force.
Joining me now is Constance Rice.
She's a civil rights lawyer and co-director of the Advancement Project, a public policy and legal action group in Los Angeles.
Welcome.
Thank you.
So the situation is eerily familiar to many Los Angeles residents.
Police repeatedly have to explain themselves to angry residents about their excessive use of force.
What is different in this case?
Right, what local communities do.
But still, I mean, based on what you've just explained, the system does end up picking winners and losers.
(Through translator) If there's nothing wrong, I won't ask her to come over.
It's a three-hour round trip for her, so a visit takes up half her day.
I tell her I'm fine.
I'm alive and kicking.
What's there to come over and see?
And I'm Alex Chadwick.
In animal lore, elephants famously never forget.
Now, a study published in the British Royal Society's Biology Letters finds evidence that it may be true, and it might help save elephants from climate change drought.

The study is from the Wildlife Conservation Society in New York and the Zoological Society of London, but the research was carried out in Tanzania in east Africa, where we've reached one of the scientists, Charles Foley.
Hello, Charles Foley.
What is your data here?
This goes back to a study, actually, from 1993?
In 1993, in Tarangre National Park, which is where the study was done, there was a severe drought.
And, in fact, the drought lasted for two years.
And there was very little food to eat, and many animals of various different species died at that time.
Many of the elephants left the national park but not all of them.
And the ones that stayed behind suffered very heavily.
40 percent of all the infants left behind died during that drought.
These elephants are - they're in family groups or kinds of clans.
So one clan stayed in the park, and two other clans left, and these groups had much better survival rates.
And you noticed these groups were led by older females, old enough so that they were alive when a previous drought had occurred 35 years earlier?
When the family groups in the clans that had left the park, when they returned, we were amazed to find that the majority of them still had their infants.
In fact, they had suffered less than 10 percent infant mortality.

The key feature differentiating the two clans that left the park and the third clan that remained was that these clans that left had several older females in their late 30s, mid 40s that would probably have survived - have been about five or 10 years old during the previous drought of that magnitude.
So you hypothesized from this that these elephants would have remembered the location of water holes or places outside their normal boundary where they might have gone 35 years earlier.
Isn't that an awful long time for them to have retained this memory?
There's going to be strong selection pressure on these animals to actually have those excellent memories.
Droughts in east Africa have a periodicity of about 45 to 50 years.

And females that can survive those two droughts and remember where they went in the previous droughts are going to be very well placed to lead their family group to safe areas, to drought refuge areas where they can find food and water.
You've been studying elephants quite a long time?
Well, it's been 15 years now since I've been working in Tarangire National Park.
And we know about 800 elephants individually, and we follow over 30 family groups.
So you must have encountered this idea of elephant memory before.
Still, the idea of being able to remember a single trip that occurred 35 years earlier, does that surprise you about elephants?
Yes and no. They remain with the family group for a very long time.
The young males don't leave families until they're about eight to 10 years old, and that suggests that they have an awful lot of learning to do.
And elephants appear to show post reproductive survival.
Most animals in the animal kingdom, they die quite quickly after they stop reproducing, at least the females do.
The very few animals that appear to really survive for long periods after they stop reproducing are Orka whales, Pilot whales, and possibly elephants.

This clan that remained in the park and didn't leave it, it was led by younger females because there was this wave of poaching in the 70s and 80s, and so the older females in that group, they'd all been killed for their tusks?
Poaching is a selective process.
The poachers obviously want to shoot the animals with the biggest tusks.
They first of all eliminate the old males, and then they turn their attention to the females, and they shoot the old ones.
They target the old females and the matriarchs.
What happens is that, if you have a very heavily poached population, you may end up with no females or no individuals in that population over the age of 30.
In Tarangire, what happened was that some of the family groups had remained inside the national park in the height of the poaching and still retained relatively normal age structures.
We could really look at these groups and see what did it mean to be led by a old matriarch or a young matriarch?
You're very concerned about this at the moment.
I mean, as you write in the paper, the reason you undertake going through this data now is climate change is already producing more severe, more frequent droughts in east Africa.
So if these elephants are to survive, the memory of where these water holes are, it's going to be very important.
That is going to be a real problem for the wildlife.
What I imagine we'll find is that it's those family groups that have the older matriarchs which are better placed to survive this.

Because one of the interesting things that this study has brought to light is the fact that the impacts of something like poaching can be greatly ameliorated if a few old females are retained in the population.
But equally, the converse is true.
If a few of those old females are lost, it will impact not just that family group but may impact many other animals in the clans or in the entire population.
As climate change takes grip, these animals are going to become more and more important in their populations.
Charles Foley is a researcher with the Wildlife Conservation Society speaking with us from his elephant study sight in Tanzania.
Charles, thank you.
Thank you.
And now we're joined by commentator and comedian W.
Kamau Bell.
He hosts the CNN show ""United Shades of America,"" which, among other things, looks at race in this country.
Thanks so much for being with us this morning, Kamau.
Thanks for having me.
It's hard to know where to begin with a week like this - the events in Dallas, the police shootings of two men, Philando Castile and Alton Sterling.
What are you thinking about now?
What's the - what's the thing that's on top of your mind at this moment?
Yeah.
We used to call those cheap thrills back in the day.
Yeah.
This is a continuation of a very dysfunctional dynamic between poor communities and the police.

What's different about this is that you have an El Salvadoran-American, Central American immigrant community enclave in South Central that is reacting to police use of force in the same way that poor African-Americans do.
That's different.

If you look at the reaction, for example, to the Guatemalan-American and Guatemalan immigrant and Central American immigrant community in Rampart Division, where you had the last police scandal, where you had gangster cops planting evidence and so forth, the community stuck with the cops; they didn't have any problem with the abuses.
And so the Central American immigrant community does not have the reaction of poor African-Americans because the history is different.
Let's listen to how the LAPD defended itself yesterday at a news conference.
Assistant Police Chief George Gascon spoke about the shooting.
The suspect is the one that committed a criminal event.
The suspect is the one that prompted what occurred here.
And I think it's very important that we do not confuse sorrow with any indication that we believe that our officers did anything wrong.
So will that wash with residents?
Will that be taken seriously?

What's interesting about this is that there ought to be a little more room to consider the mistakes, if any, and the judgments or misjudgments, if any, on the part of the police, and an assumption that when cops go into rescue a baby and a 17-year-old from a crazed man with a gun who's shooting at the neighborhood that there ought to be a little more identification with the circumstances that the officers are facing.
They're going in to try to save you.
And the question is: Why can't the community wait for an investigation and at least give a little goodwill to say, you know, `They were trying to save the baby and the daughter'?
Well, Connie, let's go back a little bit and if you could tell me why the community would have that immediate negative reaction and not give the police even an inch of reasonable doubt.
You're seeing the history of LAPD.
The community's not looking at a single use of force; they're looking at 80 years of abuse.
LAPD has had a very glorious history of being a paramilitary police force, the Marine Corps of policing.
It's effective, but it's suppression containment.
And cops will tell you, `We're the thin blue line.
We're here to contain chaos.
When you have that kind of policing, and we in LA have demanded that kind of policing, it has created a 60-to-80-year history of baggage.
You can just name the names.
And that's dangerous, because it keeps the community from seeing this incident for what it is, evaluating it on the facts, trying to see whether the judgments the officers made were reasonable.
There's just no room for the normal process because it's loaded down with the baggage of LAPD's history.
Constance Rice is a civil rights lawyer.
She's also the co-director of the Advancement Project, a public policy and legal action group in Los Angeles.
As a lawyer, she represents both community members and police officers.
